xxl.core.cursors.joins
Class MultiWaySortMergeJoin

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor
      xxl.core.cursors.joins.MultiWaySortMergeJoin
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator, Cursor
public class MultiWaySortMergeJoin
extends AbstractCursor

A sort-merge implementation of the join operator over n input iterations. The sorted inputs are traversed simultaneously following a global ordering. The objects are stored in SweepAreas und used to find and generate results until the traversal reaches a point where they are no longer needed.

Field Detail

inputs

protected Iterator[] inputs
The input iterations holding the data.

joinPredicates

protected Predicate[][] joinPredicates
Parts of the global join predicate which are checked on partially created results. Each predicate can be null if no condition should be checked. These predicate fragements can be used for pruning the number of possible join results during the calculation of the join operation.

sweepOrders

protected int[][] sweepOrders
This array determines the order in which an input iteration is tested against the other input iterations.

comparators

protected Comparator[][] comparators
The comparators that are used for comparing elements of the different input iterations.

heap

protected Heap heap
A heap that is used for determining the current minimum of all inputs.

sweepAreas

protected SweepArea[] sweepAreas
The sweep-areas that are used for storing the elements of the input iterations and probing these elements for matches.

isEmpty

protected boolean[] isEmpty
An array of boolean flags determining whether the corresponding sweep-area is empty.

newResult

protected Function newResult
A function that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple).

r

protected int r
The number of input iterations to be joined.

d

protected int d
The current recursion depth of the join algorithm.

queryTuples

protected Object[] queryTuples
Partial result of the join. The array is used to collect the elements of the different input iterations during the calculation of the join operation.

querys

protected Iterator[] querys
The query iterations on the internally used sweep-areas that are currently used for the construction of the result-tuple stored in queryTuples.

currentInput

protected int currentInput
The index of the input iteration that currently provides the minimum of all inputs. This minimal element is determined by the heap stored in the field heap.

Constructor Detail

MultiWaySortMergeJoin

public MultiWaySortMergeJoin(Iterator[] inputs,
                             SweepArea[] sweepAreas,
                             int[][] sweepOrders,
                             Predicate[][] joinPredicates,
                             Comparator[][] comparators,
                             Function newResult)
Creates a new multi-way sort-merge join of the given input iterations using the given sweep-areas to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results.

Precondition: The input cursors have to be sorted!

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). Further a set of comparators have to be specified, in order to compare the elements of different input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Note: In order to speed up self joins one can use TeeCursor to get several instances of an priveously sorted iterator.

Parameters:
inputs - the sorted input iterations to be joined.
sweepAreas - the sweep-areas used for storing elements of the input iterations and probing for join results.
sweepOrders - the order in which an input iteration is tested against the other input iterations.
joinPredicates - parts of the global join predicate which are checked on partially created results. Each predicate can be null if no condition should be checked. These predicate fragements can be used for pruning the number of possible join results during the calculation of the join operation.
comparators - the comparators that are used for comparing elements of the different input iterations.
newResult - a function that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple).

MultiWaySortMergeJoin

public MultiWaySortMergeJoin(Iterator[] inputs,
                             SweepArea[] sweepAreas,
                             Comparator[][] comparators,
                             Function newResult)
Creates a new multi-way sort-merge join of the given input iterations using the given sweep-areas to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results.

Precondition: The input cursors have to be sorted!

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). Further a set of comparators have to be specified, in order to compare the elements of different input iterations. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Note: In order to speed up self joins one can use TeeCursor to get several instances of an priveously sorted iterator.

Parameters:
inputs - the sorted input iterations to be joined.
sweepAreas - the sweep-areas used for storing elements of the input iterations and probing for join results.
comparators - the comparators that are used for comparing elements of the different input iterations.
newResult - a function that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple).
Method Detail

defaultSweepOrders

public static int[][] defaultSweepOrders(int r)
Creates a default query order for the sweep-areas used to store the elements of the input iterations. For every input iteration the other sweep-areas are queried according to their index.

Parameters:
r - the number of input iterations.
Returns:
a default query order for the sweep-areas used to store the elements of the input iterations.

open

public void open()
Opens the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the internally used heap, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor

close

public void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close the internally used heap, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
true if the join operator has more elements.

nextObject

protected Object nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class. The number of inputs to use can be specified by using the command line parameter. If none are used, the default of three is used.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
